qas.question: What are strains that are resistant to antibiotics called sometimes?
What was a once almost controlled disease that is coming back do to resistance?
How many new infections of resistant TB are reported per year?
What is the acronym used to describe resistant TB?
What are strains that are resistant to tuberculosis called sometimes?
What was a once almost controlled antibiotic that is coming back to do resistance?
How many new infections of bacteria are reported per year?
What is the acronym used to describe enzymes?
What is a newly identified enzyme conveying bacterial resistance to a broad range of strains and species?

context: Antibacterial-resistant strains and species, sometimes referred to as "<a0_0><b4_0>superbugs<b4_0/><a0_0/>", now contribute to the emergence of diseases that were for a while well controlled. For example, emergent bacterial strains causing <a1_0>tuberculosis<a1_0/> (TB) that are resistant to previously effective antibacterial treatments pose many therapeutic challenges. Every year, nearly <a2_0><b6_0>half a million<b6_0/><a2_0/> new cases of multidrug-resistant <b5_0>tuberculosis<b5_0/> (<a3_0><b7_0>MDR-TB<b7_0/><a3_0/>) are estimated to occur worldwide. For example, <b8_0>NDM-1<b8_0/> is a newly identified enzyme conveying bacterial resistance to a broad range of beta-lactam antibacterials. The United Kingdom's Health Protection Agency has stated that "most isolates with NDM-1 enzyme are resistant to all standard intravenous antibiotics for treatment of severe infections."
